trial_identification.studytitle: Traditional portable vacuum dressings versus simple non-mechanized negative pressure dressings in the treatment of lower limb split thickness skin grafting.
trial_identification.scientifictitle: A study assessing graft survival in patients requiring split thickness skin grafts by comparing non-mechanised negative pressure dressings to mechanised vacuum dressing

conditions.healthcondition: Split thickness skin grafting to lower limb

interventions.interventions: non-mechanised [belovac] dressing. Jelonet, dry sterile foam with belovac drain, occlusive dressing are placed on the wound at the time of surgery and remain in situ for 5/6 days post-op. Negative pressure via the belovac drain is apllied for the entire duration. Dressing is then taken down by member of research team, photograph taken and reviewed by blinded team member.
interventions.comparator: Commercial KCI vaccum dressings with commercial vaccuum pump placed on the wound at the time of surgery and remain in situ for 5/6 days post-op with continuous pressure of 125mmHg. Dressing is then taken down by member of research team, photograph taken and reviewed by blinded team member.

primaryOutcome.timepoint: Operations and follow up were performed between July 2008 and January 2009

primaryOutcome.outcome: day 5 graft survival as assessed by health care professionals upon removal of graft at this time.
primaryOutcome.timepoint: 5/6 days post-op is the recognised gold standard for removal of dressing and assessment of graft take

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: patients requiring split thickness skin grafting of lower limb
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Patient not requiring split thickness skin grafting of the lower limb

trial_design.sequence: patients were allocated sequentially. The first patient presenting was placed in group A, the next in group B, the next in group A and so on until enrollment was complete

ethicsAndSummary.summary: Patients presenting to Gold Coast health service requiring Split thickness skin grafting of the lower limb.

ethicscommitee.ethicname: Gold Coast Health Service District Human research ethics committee

contact.name: Dr Ben McArdle
